bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, May 6, 1921

div1.p: Hanson discusses the spread of yellow fever in Peru, and the use of fish to control mosquitoes. He also discusses funding issues.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, May 6, 1921
div1.opener:
COPY
Trujillo
May 6, 1921
Mr. Wickliffe Rose, Field Manager,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N.Y.
My Dear Mr. Rose:
div1.p:
I cabled you before leaving Chiclayo, and also after arriv-
ing in Trujillo. As you know I came down here in response to a notice
about the appearance of a case of yellow fever in this place. When this
case was first announced by the local physicians there was a great clamor
denying that it could be true. Even the Prefecto sent me several tele-
grams before I came insisting that it was all unfounded rumor, which was
causing a tremendous amount of damage to the Department.

I arranged to come down on the first possible opportunity, to
investigate and establish the diagnosis, but on account of the difficulties
we have had with the itinerary of the ships, since the epidemic, there was
a delay of about a week before I could get here. I first tried to go
overland in our Ford, but when I got to Ucupe we found the there was so
much water in the road across the desert that we could not get through,
and had to go back and wait for steamer.

I arrived here on the 3rd and at once went to see the case, a
Japanese, who was then in beginning convalesence, an absolutely typical case,
with an abundance of albumen in urine, still with bleeding about the gums,
very yellow even to the tongue itself, eyes typical, profound prostration
and in fact with everything one needs to make a diagnosis of yellow fever.
There could be no doubt in my mind about him.

With this information we have set about reorganizing the work,
and have decided that this will be the most important as well as the stra-
tegic place for the main office for the continuation of the campaign.
The Lambayeque situation seems to be under complete control, and for the
future I only expect a few cases during the period of life of the infected
adult stegomyia. There too the temperature has fallen considerably pro-
longing the period of development of the larvae which helps very decidedly.
In this place, Trujillo, we are at the real front of the advance of the
epidemic, and with my presence here I do not feel that the campaign is in
any danger of being lost, that is with the new program which we have
organized for this section, and with a considerable training force at our
disposal. For this purpose I have called Mr. Richardson and Sr.Manuel
Machado and my former Lima Secretary Sr. Ramirez who also is a trained
stegomyia inspector.

In accordance with the information available here regarding the
cases, I do not expect a pronounced outbreak before next week or the week
following and possibly even later than that. It seems that we have been
Mr. Wickliffe Rose
May 6, 1921
2.
notified of this in its very beginning which means a great deal in con-
trolling and stamping it out. In the past epidemics we have not had a chance
to take a hold until the thing was well established and had had a chance
to spread all over the territory in question. Here we also have the
advantage that there has been a considerable amount of work done, es-
pecially in the Province of Pacasmayo which as you know has been under the
direction of Dr. Ricardo Mendoza, with a number of trained inspectors.
The work there and the percentage of breeding I have already reported, in
my letter written aboard the Aysen.

Since arriving I have reviewed the situation and find to my chagrin
that the work here has not been done as well as I had hoped, and the breed-
ing is very high. In the next few weeks I expect that we shall have an
epidemic here in Trujillo in spite of all we can do. I say this for the
reason that there have been two definite cases, and one other which I have
seen and believe to be yellow fever. It is clear then that there are adult
stegomyia infected and in their period of incubation which means more cases
of yellow fever. This according to all the rules of the game will come
to pass notwithstanding the intensive campaign which we are organizing now.

We are using fish wherever it is possible. For the present we are
catching small fish in the fresh water ponds and streams and distributing
them for the wells and the tanks. In Pacasmayo we have some “millions”
received from Dr. Pareja in Guayaquil, and are fixing up a hatchery there,
so as to have on hand for distribution. We have also distributed fish of
the type received from Guayaquil and those caught locally in the Department
of Lambayeque. In addition we have the regular inspection of the “boticas,
tinajas” etc.

Here I think I will do a little fumigation in the first foci found.
This I know is not generally considered worth while, and I do not do it as
a rule, but the fewer cases we can have the smaller will be the danger that
some one is going to break through the land quarantine and spread the
epidemic south. The south is the section to be defended if we are to acc-
omplish our objective of eliminating the fever during the year 1921. I do
not think that there is any real danger of it going back to Ecuador, but
on this point I will soon have more detailed information.

I believe I told you that I arranged with Dr. Enrique Caballero
of Catacaos to serve in the sanitary campaign, and I have directed him to
make a preliminary inspection of the Piura frontier, both for the effi-
cacy of the stegomyia work and for any rumors of cases of suspicious illness,
that we may have as complete data as possible from all sides of the present
campaign. As soon as he arrives I will have him make a series of investi-
gations in the ports to the south, between here and Callao, to find out if
there have been any sick with symptoms resembling yellow fever. The
“Medicos Sanitarios” should be the ones to furnish this information, but in
the first place they know nothing about the bedside appearance of yellow
fever, and in the second place they are nearly all of them corrupted by
the rotten politics of the country to the extent that they could not be de-
pended upon to inform me correctly if they did know of a case. To me this
seems a perfectly justifiable expense, and means a great deal for the
ultimate object of this campaign. Dr. Caballero is an immune and can travel
Mr. Wickliffe Rose
May 6, 1921
3.
freely without any quarantine restrictions.

In the Chiclayo office we are working up a resume of the re-
ported cases to date and will send you this together with the financial
statement for the past month.

I have worked up a budget for the Governments share of the
campaign expenses for this Department, which is confined principally to
the Province of Trujillo. In the budget which I sent you as the one
proposed for the International Health Board, I indicated salaries for
inspectors for the principal ports of the Department, but so far I have
not engaged any men for these positions, nor do I have any men in sight
at the present time with qualifications for these places. When I do
place them it will probably be with salaries lower than those indicated
in the budget. I have indicated maximum salaries in practically all those
places, and expect to economize on those indicated where it can be done
with safety. The budget for this campaign can not be made very rigid on
account of the constantly changing conditions, and both the budget for the
International Health Board and that for the Peruvian Government will have
to be more or less flexible. For that reason in order to make a proper
account of expenditure it will be clearer if we send you a copy of the
financial statement to the Government covering the expenditure of Govern-
ment funds and a copy of the financial statement of International Health
Board funds to the Government, which will give a complete check in both
places of the moneys spent. I have sent copies of the budgets to both
places.

I am hoping to find some letters from you on my return to
Chiclayo, in response to some of those which I have already sent upon the
organization and on our first financial statement.

I am told that the exchange has risen considerably in the last
few days, which makes me regretful that I did not convert the entire amount
of the last $15,000.00 which you appropriated. It would have meant a great
deal more peruvian money. I desisted from doing so on account of the
wording of the letter of the Auditor of the Foundation. I still have
$10,000.00 which have not yet been converted.

I shall be obliged to convert some of this soon for the expenses
in the Province of Pacasmayo.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, (Signed) Henry Hanson,M.D.,
Director of Sanitary Campaign.
